newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat ends up on commercial buying, weather.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat ends up on commercial buying, weather.

text.p: CBOT soft red winter wheat futures ended higher Thursday, boosted by commercial buying and forecasts for dry weather in the US Plains, traders said.
"Commercials have been buyers again today in the wheat pit and I think that's why we're up," said one floor trader.
The wheat market has fallen to levels that end-users are finding attractive, so over the past two days, traders have noted fresh export sales and commercial buying.
Overnight Wednesday, Japan bought 60,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat. That purchase followed moderate to heavy buying by other Asian countries this week.
Long-term forecasts for hot, dry weather in the U.S. southern Plains generated concern about the developing hard red winter wheat crops and lifted prices, traders said.
"They do need rain in the northwestern part of Kansas, but otherwise world weather is favorable for wheat," said Victor Lespinasse, trader with Dean Witter brokerage in Chicago.
Several private forecasters see hot and dry temperatures in the Central and Southern Plains through May, and the freeze-damaged crop is said to need cool and moist weather.
CBOT wheat settled two to five cents per bushel higher, with July up 4-3/4 at $4.09.
Traders also eagerly awaited final results from the Wheat Quality Council Tour's Kansas wheat tour because there is vast uncertainty over how much freeze damage the crop suffered.
After the market closed, the tour forecast Kansas wheat production to be 336.2 million bushels and estimated the states average yield at 36.8 bushels per acre.
Lower-than-expected weekly export sales of 176,200 tonnes had little impcat on market prices Thursday. The sales came in below expectations for 200,000 to 300,000 tonnes.
On the day, Cargill bought 3.5 million bushels July, FIMAT bought three million, Refco bought two million December, and LIT sold four million bushels, pit sources said.
In options trade, Tenco bought 100 July $4.00 puts and 100 $4.00 July calls. Tenco also bought 100 July $3.60 calls and sold 100 $3.60 puts.
Volume was estimated at 18,000 contracts, versus Wednesday's final volume of 15,357 contracts, according to CBOT data.
